div1.p:
Scientific Achievements of the Army Medical Corps
Heroes of the Conquest of Yellow Fever.

Memo for
an address for
Gen. Ireland

President and Members of the Illinois State Medical Association, Ladies and
Gentlemen:

When I received the gracious and friendly invitation of your Secretary to meet you here
tonight it seemed at first impossible that I would be able to leave Washington
in the middle of the short session of Congress when I must at all times be ready
to answer the calls of Congressional Committees for information which bears upon
the needs of the Army. But when I observed that this meeting was intended to
do honor not to individuals merely, but to the Corps as a whole, and not only to
commemorate the glorious episode of the conquest of yellow fever but to embrace
also the more recent fine accomplishments of the service of which I am at present
the Chief, I felt that the call to me was imperative and must be obeyed.

A Spanish officer who resided for some years in Washington used to refer to the
war of 1898 as the “pleasantest of all wars”. He referred of course to the absence
of hatred between the opposing combattants and the kindly sympathy which we showed
towards our Spanish prisoners of war of which he was one. This war though it was
marked by no bitterness and little bloodshed had far reaching and permanent results.
For our country it brought it out of its attitude of isolation and introspection
and made it a world power. For the Medical Department of the Army with which we
are especially concerned tonight, it rudely awoke us from an easy life of small
things and thrust upon us large responsibilities in strange environments and distant
lands. To this call all that was best in the medical service responded nobly,
and some among them “seized the skirts of happy chance” and because our benefactors
by accomplishments which you have shown a generous desire to celebrate tonight.

The Army Medical School had been established in 1891 by General Sternberg who and
has been called the Father of Bacteriology in America, I think I may say, the
-2-
first of our Surgeon Generals who had made a name in the field of scientific
research. Within its first decade while yet a small tree the School began to
bring forth rich fruits. From its chair of bacteriology Reed and his assistant
Carroll went forth to fight the dragon of yellow fever. One of its young men
who had studied:-

(1) Parasitology under Stiles, (who then gave lectures to its classes) was after
the war stationed in
a small town in Porto Rico where he observed among the country population
the devast ting blight of tropical anaemia. He recognised in the intestinal
discharges of these people a microscopic parasite, the hookworm, which was
at that time not known to have invaded our hemisphere. Knowledge in young Bailey
Ashford bred active, and he instituted the first organized campaign against
this enemy of the poor, which, so far as I am aware, had ever been instituted.
Of the vast fruitfulness of his work in Porto Rico, which later was extended to
our Southern States and under the Rockefeller Institute to many lands you are
all doubtless aware.

(2) I am sure that nome of you have forgotten the terrible ravages of typhoid
fever in our mobilization camps in the Spanish war. This epidemic was studied
with fruitful results by a Board of which Walter Reed was the chairman, but
it was not until Major Frederick Russell improved the method of Wright of the
British Army and perfected a vaccine which was highly protective without
excessivily severe reactions that this minacious of diseases which slew our
young men and maidens in their prime and was the greatest menace to the
efficiency of armies could be controlled. So effective was this great triumph
of preventive medicine that introduced into our army in 1909, by 1912 typhoid
fever had disappeared from our military hospitals.

(3) The attention of our profession is now being called to the appearance
of a severe fever called undulant fever the infection of which occurs in cattle,
goats and swine and is not infrequently transmitted to mankind. It is worthy
of note that the first endemic focus of this disease in the United States was
discovered, recognized and reported twenty two years ago by two young army
doctors, undergraduates of the Army Medical School.

It was then called Malta fever. Their report may be found in (Jour. A.U.S. or
Report Surgeon General).

(4) In our Philippine possessions our medical officers encountered a strange
disease beri-beri which paralized the limbs and caused many deaths. Among our
Filopino Scouts it was by far the greatest cause of disability and death. The
studies of Ashburn Vedder, Siler and others demonstrated that it was a
deficiency disease in which a certain constituent now known as Vitamin C was
lacking, and it could be quickly cured and prevented by simple changes in the
dietary.

(5) Dengue fever occasionally invades our Southern States and though not a
fatal disease is a very painful one. In Manila it is the greatest cause of
admissions to hospitals. Its epidemiology has been studied by Army Medical
Boards and one of my assistants Colonel Silver, at present in my office, has
by a remarkable system of experiments following closely the procedure of Reed,
and like him making use of the generous self devotion of our soldiers, has
demonstrated that it is a non fetal foster brother of yellow fever, transmitted
by the same mosquito and with the same incubation period and similar clinical
features.

(6) During the World War the Medical Department in France encountered a formidable
fever which attacked the soldiers of our allies in the trenches called trench
fever. To study it the Chief Surgeon called upon Colonel Richard Strong who
-4-
had been formerly in the Medical Corps (and had been a student at the Army
Medical School under Major Reed)

That familiar but not popular companion of the soldier in the field, called by
our boys the cootie was under suspicion of carrying this disease and Strong
determined to follow step by step the procedure of Reed's classical experiments.
Volunteers were needed and were called for from an ambulance company of the
Medical Department. Their commander had them fall in, explained to them the
lives and painful illness that might result from the infection but the importance
to the Army of determining its cause and method of prevention. He then said that
any men who were willing to offer themselves should step one pace to the front.
The entire company stepped forward. Does not this show the vitality of the
glorious tradition of the yellow fever volunteers of 1900, (one of whom we have
with us here tonight). “As one lamp lights another, nor grows less
So nobleness enkindleth nobleness.”

Perhaps you may not unjustly suspect me of imitating the young children who
when they have strawberries for supper carefully save the biggest until the
last. So I have delayed to mention until now that triumph of preventive
medicine which, so far as our safety and happiness are concerned, is the
greatest since Jenner's discovery of vaccination, the conquest of yellow fever.
This came about as you all know in two phases: The first was the brilliant and
dramatic demonstration by Reed of how that dreaded and mysterious disease was
transmitted. The second was the wonderful campaign of Gorgas and his Lieutenants
in which with unwearied patience, admirable skill in the adaption of the agencies
available to the new warfare and an unshakeable determination and faith that
ridicule and doubt could not discourage an opposition in high places defeat,
gave us first Havana cleansed of the ancient plague and then, after long years
of conflict, the Isthumus free from the curse of centuries and made a safe
-5-
pathway for the commerce of the world.

When Reed was sent to Cuba by General Sternberg in June 1900 taking with him his
laboratory assistant Carroll, the other two members of this famous commission
were already there wearing the uniform of the Army and busy in its service.
Agrimusite was at the head of the Army Medical Laboratory in Havana. His
classmate in graduation at Columbia Medical School in New York, the gifted
and accomplished Lazear was on duty at Columbia Barracks, the Army Headquarters,
a few miles southwest of Havana. Lazear by Postgraduate study of malaria
in Italy and at John Hopkins was admirably fitted for the work with mosquitoes
which was to furnish the clues which solved the mystery of the double trap
of the infection afterward spoken of as extrinsic and intrinsic incubation.

And while the Board sits on an August day discussing the way in which the
problem could be attacked let us say a word of tribute to Dr. Carlos Finlay
born of Scotch parents but a native of the West Indies, who for fifteen years
had argued on epidemiological grounds that yellow fever was transmitted by the
common household mosquito of those regions. He was a gentle and lovable old
man, learned in the science of medicine, but a dreamer whose dream came true,
but he could not demonstrate it so that others could see it. A Moses he
was, who saw the promised land from Pisgah's height, but to him it was not
given to leave the desert of sterile theory and lead the children of science
into the productive land of demonstrated fact. At this critical time Reed was
called north in a flying trip to rescue the precious records of the Typhoid
Board whose loss was threatened by the death of Dr. Shakespeare. When he
returned a month later Carroll and the cavalryman Private Dean, known in
the records as XY were convalescent from experimental yellow fever and
Lazear was dead. But he had left behind him the precious notes from which
-6-
Reed unraveled the hidden secret of the centuries. The evidence was however
incomplete, the controls were defective. What was then to be done? All
efforts to infect laboratory animals had failed. The dread responsibility of
experiment on human beings had to be faced or nothing would be accomplished,
and Lazear would have died in vain. Fortunately at that time the Governor
of Cuba was a great man and one who held at the same time two commissions. He
was a Major General of Volunteers and he was a Captain of the Medical Corps
in the Regular Army. So to Leonard Wood went Walter Reed and received his
approval and promise both of moral and pecuniary support. But this was not
quite enough, he also have in so dubious an enterprise where the charge
of murder might be laid at his door he wished like a good medical soldier
to have the approval of his Chief the Surgeon General. There was another
reason why he wished to hasten north. Curiously enough there was another
commission of American Medical Officers who had for over a y year been
studying the cause of yellow fever in Havana and had arrived at a diametrically
opposite conclusion from Reeds commission, for they were about to report
to the American Public Health Association which was to meet in this city of
Indianapolis, that the cause of yellow fever was the Sanarelli bacillus.
The Academy of Medicine of France had already accepted Sanarelli's organism
and if the American Public Health Association should become committed to it,
the acceptance of the truth which he hoped to prove would be indeed made
hard for him. So again he hastened northward, saw the Surgeon General, came
to Indianapolis and routed in a fiery debate the advocateds of Sanarelli.
In three weeks he was back in Cuba. General Wood gave the promised money, he
built Camp Lazear in a lonely valley at a distance from all infections.
Agrimusite bred and infected mosquitos and all was ready except the men who
should face the dread experiment. He had planned to get Spanish immigrants
-7-
who were then pouring into Havana and furnish[i]ng non0-immune fuel for the flames
of pestalence, but difficulties arose, the secret got out and the papers of
Havana uttered indignant protests against the cruel exploitation of these
simple peasants by heartless American scientists. At this fateful emergency
came forward two men, young Americans who knew well the risk they ran and also
the vast importance to humanity of the question at issue. These two men
John J. Moran, Field Clerk at Headquarters and Private John R. Kissinger,
Hospital Corps whom we have with us here tonight, stepped into the breach
without desire of reward when the chance came to do a great an heroic and
noble act. They simply stepped forward and did it simply, modestly and
without heroics. After them came twelve other American soldiers who suffered
attacks of yellow fever and four who went through the long and repulsive
in experience, and, as it then deemed, the more dangerous one of
sleeping in the fouled infected bedding. With them were also certain Spaniards
also who later endured the test for the gold that was offered them, and the not
less prized immunity from future attacks. Will you permit me to read the names
of these brave men which with the memory of their services to humanity we
should carry in our hearts.
